column1: The official language of Nicaragua is Spanish; however
column2: Nicaraguans on the Caribbean coast speak indigenous languages and also English. The communities located on the Caribbean coast also have access to education in their native languages. Additionally
column3: Nicaragua has four extinct indigenous languages.

column1: Phonetics and phonologySome characteristics of Nicaraguan phonology include:
/s/ at the end of a syllable or before a consonant is pronounced [h].
j (/x/) is a [h].
There is a clear distinction between /l/ and /r/

column2: /z/ and in some cases /c/ (as in cerrar) are pronounced as [s].

column1: == Indigenous languages ==
Several indigenous peoples on the Caribbean coast still use their native language
column2: the main languages being Miskito language
column4: and Rama language. Other Indigenous languages spoken include Garifuna.

column1: MiskitoMiskito is a Misumalpan language spoken by the Miskito people in northeastern Nicaragua along the Caribbean coast
column2: especially in the North Caribbean Coast Autonomous Region. The Miskito language is the most widely spoken indigenous language in Nicaragua
column3: this is because the Miskito people also hold the highest population of Indigenous people in the country.

column1: SumoSumo (also known as Sumu) is a Misumalpan language spoken in Nicaragua by the Sumo people. There is wide dialectal variation
column2: and sometimes the major dialects may be listed as separate languages.

column1: RamaRama is one of the indigenous languages of the Chibchan family spoken by the Rama people on the island of Rama Cay and south of lake Bluefields on the Caribbean Coast of Nicaragua. The Rama language is severely endangered. Their language was described as "dying quickly for lack of use" as early as the 1860s. By 1980
column2: the Rama were noted as having "all but lost their original ethnic language"
column3: and had become speakers of a form of English creole instead
column4: Rama Cay Creole which is spoken by 8
column6: 000 people.Language revival efforts began in 1980–1981 under the Sandinistas however
column7: they were not successful. The fieldwork for the first dictionary of Rama was done during this time by Robin Schneider
column8: a graduate student from the University of Berlin. In 1992
column9: only approximately 36 fluent speakers could be found among an ethnic population of 649 individuals in 1992
column10: of whom only a few scattered individuals live outside Nicaragua. The number of speakers on Rama Cay island was only 4 in 1992
column11: due to language shift to English that engendered Rama Cay Creole.

== Minority languages ==
Nicaragua has many minority groups. Many ethnic groups in Nicaragua
column2: such as the Chinese Nicaraguans and Palestinian Nicaraguans
column3: have maintained their ancestral languages while also speaking Spanish and/or English. Minority languages include Chinese

column1: == Extinct languages ==
Nicaragua has a total of 4 extinct languages:
NahuatNahuat
column3: is a  dialect of the Nahuatl language
column4: belonging to the Uto-Aztecan language family. This language was spoken by the Pipil-Nicarao people
column5: also referred to simply as the Nicaraos. Nahuat became the lingua franca during the 16th century. A hybrid form of Nahuat-Spanish was spoken by many Nicaraguans up until the 19th century.

column1: MangueThe Mangue language
column3: consisted of several dialects spoken in western Nicaragua by Chorotega natives. Mangue is a language closely related to the Chiapanec language spoken in Mexico
column4: and is classified as belonging to the Oto-Manguean language family. In the Monimbó neighborhood of the city of Masaya
column5: there are many Chorotega natives but the language that they speak is Spanish.

column1: SubtiabaThe Subtiaba language was an Oto-Manguean language which was spoken on the Pacific slope of Nicaragua by the indigenous Subtiaba people (also sometimes referred to as Maribios
column4: Edward Sapir wrote an article based on scant evidence arguing for the inclusion of Subtiaba in his hypothesized Hokan languages group. Others have linked Subtiaba to the Jicaque and Tol languages of Honduras
column5: but it is generally accepted that Subtiaba is an Oto-Manguean language that shares a close affinity with the Tlapanec language of Mexico. When Sapir wrote about Subtiaba in 1925
column6: it was already very endangered or moribund.

column1: MatagalpaThe Matagalpa language was a Misumalpan language spoken by the indigenous Matagalpa people. In 1981
column2: the population of the Matagalpa people was estimated at 18
column4: 000. The Matagalpa people live in the Central highlands of Nicaragua in the departments of Matagalpa and Jinotega. Matagalpa became extinct in the 19th century; the eponymous people now speak Spanish. Only a few short word lists remain. It was closely related to the Cacaopera language.
